article.abstract: Erosion of fertile topsoil means severe land degradation and yield loss. Here, we show that reformation of the fertile topsoil and crop yield increase is possible by good agricultural management within a few decades. Evidence relies on a unique long‑term field experiment in NE Germany where the sandy Luvisol topsoil was excavated in 1964 and refilled with subsoil material. Undisturbed trials served as controls, combined with no fertilisation, mineral fertilisation or mineral + organic fertilisation. After 26 years a new topsoil with SOC, N stocks and aggregate size distribution comparable to the controls had formed, corresponding to 28 Mg SOC ha⁻¹ sequestration. The former topsoil buried below the plough layer lost 30–50 % of its SOC over five decades. The study demonstrates that current agricultural tools can rapidly restore degraded arable land and contribute to climate‑change mitigation.

datasets.name: V210 historical long‑term field experiment (1964‑2019)
datasets.description: Long‑term field experiment at the Centre for Agricultural Landscape Research (ZALF) in Müncheberg, NE Germany investigating the effects of complete topsoil removal or duplication combined with different fertilisation regimes on soil organic carbon, nitrogen, aggregate formation and crop yield over five decades. The experiment was established in 1964, abandoned in 1991 and re‑established in 2015; latest measurements were taken in 2019.

datasets.researchObjective: To quantify the rate and magnitude of soil organic carbon and nitrogen recovery in a newly formed topsoil after complete topsoil loss, and to evaluate how different fertilisation regimes (none, mineral, mineral + organic) influence SOC sequestration, aggregate formation and C‑N dynamics over a 55‑year period.

overviewMap.trialDesign: Randomised complete block design with 4 replicates per treatment combination (soil manipulation × fertilisation).

soilInformation.soilType: Albic Luvisol (sandy, glacial till overlying glacio‑fluvial sands)

trialTypes: Topsoil removal (complete removal of Ap horizon)
Topsoil duplication (refill with original topsoil material)
fertilisationRegimes: Mineral fertilisation (b2) – annual 110 kg N ha⁻¹, 39 kg P ha⁻¹, 110 kg K ha⁻¹
Combined mineral + organic fertilisation (b4) – mineral 98 kg N ha⁻¹, 32 kg P ha⁻¹, 93 kg K ha⁻¹ plus organic amendments (straw, farmyard manure, slurry, solid manure, peat compost)
